summary:
bitterSWEET AGM uses unique and perfectly crafted lens- and bloom-effects, combined with superb lighting in every environment at any time and any weather condition.

From the grayish, dark foggy afternoon in Falkreath or The Reach to the bright, sunny and colorful late mornings in Rifton or Whiterun - bitterSWEET will allways look amazi

... I'd have to try another one but this is still great, the sun glare being in the way all the time is my only issue."

[/u]"Looks very nice on your screens, maybe I'll give it a try."

"Yeah mate, the sun - it's way too big. Otherwise nice colours, a bit too much of contrast which makes Everything a Little to dark,
and then we got the saturation - I mean if you got high saturation and high contrast - what you get is a Little too much of Everything. 

Otherwise this is a pretty Graphics mod / enb mod."
CelestialWarrior
[u]                                                                                                                                                                                                                      [/u][/center]







[center]If you tried out this enb, leave a comment. Wether you like the enb or not, tell it. [/center]

[color=#ffffff][size=6][color=#ffffff][size=6][center][i]bitter[/i][b]SWEET[/b] advanced graphics mod[/center][/size][/color]
[/size][/color]
To be immersed in a Videogame, or any Videogame, to feel like you are really at this place, graphics are an essential element. Bethesda made a pretty good job creating the envirmonment, the landscape, villages, dungeons, forests - but all this could not be immersive without the right post processing.
Dungeons were too bright, mountains did not feel cold. It allways felt like I was just playing a videogame. 

Most enbs aim for realism. This enb is slightly different, it aims for realism with a cinematic touch, without the use of color palettes that make it look like the videogame for the movie "300". Unique bloom effects will provide a clear vision while having a visible effect.





[font=Georgia][size=3][b]Why should I use this enb?[/b][/size][/font]

You dont need to use this enb. Anyway, If you are tired of usual enbs, give it a try, its for free :D




[b][font=Georgia][size=3]Why so many lens flares, they are not realistic![/size][/font][/b]

Every camera has lens flares, and if you wear glasses, even they make up some "lens flares". They are not unrealistic.
And btw, I f****ng LOVE lens flares!






Version 1.42 is incompatible with "reduced sunglare" optional file.
-please wait-



The enb features depth of field and ambient occlusion. By default, depth of field is activated - ambient occlusion is not. If your system can handle ambient occlusion well, feel free to activate it.
If your frames drop below a enjoyable refresh rate, you may find it appropriate to deactivate depth of field.
 
To activate/deactivate the effects open the enbseries.ini file,
scroll down to the [EFFECTS] header and set / change the values "false" or "true" to 

"EnableAmbientOcclusion="        
or
"EnableDepthOfField="

Remember to save a back up first if you are not used to enbs 






So all you need is included in the download, installation guide and all the files

just to tell it right away:
you need the binaries 132
http://enbdev.com/mod_tesskyrim_v0132.htm

and then you just follow the installation guide. DONE in under a minute


This enb should run smoothly on the average system -
higher ones can activate Ambient occlusion 
lower spec ones can deactivate depth of field if the framerate is not high enough

my system:
nvidia geforce gtx 745
12GB RAM DDR3
intel core i5    3.4 GHz
author: LaBeatBeatbox
